text:
[]
THE DIGITAL PERSONAL DATA PROTECTION ACT, 2023
The Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023 (No. 22 of 2023) was approved by the
President of India on August 11, 2023 and is now officially a law.
“This law is about how personal data (information about people) should be collected,
stored, and used in digital form. It ensures that individuals have the right to keep their
personal data safe and private. At the same time, it allows businesses, the government,
and other organizations to use personal data, but only for legal and necessary reasons.
The law also includes various rules and guidelines to ensure that personal data is
handled properly and securely.”
1. Data Fiduciary: The entity (like a company or organization) that decides how and
why personal data is processed.
2. Data Principal: The person whose data is being collected.
a. If the person is a child, their parents/guardian will act on their behalf.

a. If the person is a child, their parents/guardian will act on their behalf.
b. If the person has a disability, their legal guardian will manage their data.
3. Data Processor: A person or company that processes personal data on behalf of a
Data Fiduciary.
Illustration 1: If X (a person) voluntarily shares her personal data (like name, contact
details, or other personal information) on social media while blogging her views, then the
Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023 will not protect that data.
Illustration 2: X, an individual, opens a bank account using the mobile app or website of Y,
a bank. To complete the Know-Your-Customer requirements under law for opening a bank
account, Instead of visiting a bank, X chooses video KYC, where her identity is checked
over a live video call. Before collecting her personal data, the bank must inform/Request X
about:
1. What personal data they will collect (e.g., name, ID proof, video verification).

about:
1. What personal data they will collect (e.g., name, ID proof, video verification).
2. Why they need this data (for identity verification and account opening).
01. If a person (Data Principal) had already given permission for their personal data to be
used before this law came into effect, the following rules will apply:
a. The organization or company handling the data (Data Fiduciary) must, as
soon as possible, inform the person (Data Principal) about their data usage
through a notice.
i. The notice must clearly mention what personal data has been
collected and why it is being used.
[]
ii. The notice must explain how the person can exercise their rights
regarding their data, like correcting or deleting it.
iii. The notice must also explain how the person can file a complaint with
the Data Protection Board if they have concerns.
b. The company or organization can keep using the personal data as long as
the person does not withdraw their permission/consent. If they withdraw

the person does not withdraw their permission/consent. If they withdraw
consent, the data processing must stop.
Illustration 3: X, an individual, gave her consent to the processing of her personal data for
an online shopping app or website operated by Y, an e-commerce service provider, before
the commencement of this Act. Upon commencement of the Act, Y must promptly inform
X about what personal data is being used and why. This information should be conveyed
through email, an in-app notification, or another similarly effective method.
02. The company (Data Fiduciary) must give the individual (Data Principal) the option to
read the notice in English or any other language listed in the Eighth Schedule to the
Constitution.
The consent given by the Data Principal shall be free(Given without pressure), specific
(Clearly state what the data will be used for), informed(X should know exactly what she is
agreeing to), unconditional(There should be no hidden conditions) and unambiguous

agreeing to), unconditional(There should be no hidden conditions) and unambiguous
(There should be no confusion) with a clear affirmative action(X must actively agree such
as clicking "I Agree" instead of a default setting). The consent means that the person's data
will only be used for the stated purpose and only the necessary data will be collected and
processed for that purpose.
Illustration 4: X, an individual, downloads Y, a telemedicine app. Y requests the consent of
X for (i) the processing of her personal data for providing telemedicine services, and (ii)
accessing her mobile phone contact list, and X signifies/agrees to both the requests..
Since phone contact list is not necessary for providing telemedicine services, her consent
will only apply to the use of her personal data for telemedicine. The app cannot use her
contact list because it is not needed for the service.
If any part of the consent violates the law or goes beyond what is legally allowed, that part

If any part of the consent violates the law or goes beyond what is legally allowed, that part
of the consent will be considered invalid.This means Y cannot use X's contact list because
it is not required for the service and does not follow the law.
Illustration 5: X, an individual, buys an insurance policy using the mobile app or website
of Y, an insurer. She(X) gives to Y her consent for (i) the processing her personal data by Y
for the purpose of issuing the policy, and (ii) waiving(adhikar tyagna) her right to file a
[]
complaint to the Data Protection Board of India. Part (ii) of the consent, relating to waiver
of her right to file a complaint, shall be invalid.
Any request for consent under this law must be written in clear and simple language so
that the person(X) giving consent can easily understand it. The person must also have the
option to view the request in English or any language specified in the Eighth Schedule to

option to view the request in English or any language specified in the Eighth Schedule to
the Constitution. Additionally, the request must include the contact details of a Data
Protection Officer or another authorized person who can help the individual with any
questions or concerns about their data rights under this law.
If a person’s consent is required for using their personal data, they have the right to
withdraw that consent at any time. The process of withdrawing consent should be as
simple and easy as it was to give consent in the first place.
However, if someone withdraws their consent, they will be responsible for any
consequences that come with it. Also, withdrawing consent will not affect any data
processing that was already done before the consent was withdrawn—everything done
legally before that remains valid.
Illustration 6: X, an individual, is the user of an online shopping app or website operated

Illustration 6: X, an individual, is the user of an online shopping app or website operated
by Y, an e-commerce service provider. X consents to the processing of her personal data
by Y for the purpose of fulfilling her supply order and places an order for supply of a good
while making payment for the same. If X withdraws her consent, Y may stop enabling X to
use the app or website for placing orders, but may not stop the processing for supply of
the goods already ordered and paid for by X.
If a Data Principal withdraws her consent to the processing of personal data ,the Data
Fiduciary must stop using the person's data within a reasonable time, The Data Fiduciary
must also make sure that any third-party service providers (Data Processors) working for
them also stop using the data. However, if the law allows or requires the data fiduciary to
continue processing the data even without the person's consent, they can keep using it.

continue processing the data even without the person's consent, they can keep using it.
Illustration 7: X is a telecom company that has hired Y (a Data Processor) to send
telephone bills via email to its customers. Z, a customer of X , had previously agreed to
receive bills by email. However, Z later downloads X's mobile app and chooses to receive
bills only through the app. Because of this, X must stop sending bills via email and also
ensure that Y (the Data Processor) stops emailing the bills to the customer X.
The person (Data Principal) can give, manage, check, or withdraw their consent for data
use by the company (Data Fiduciary) with the help of a Consent Manager.
[]
The Consent Manager is responsible for managing consent on behalf of the person(Data
principal) and must follow certain rules.
Every Consent Manager must be officially registered with the Data Protection Board. For
this, they must fulfil certain technical, operational, and financial conditions.

this, they must fulfil certain technical, operational, and financial conditions.
If a person's (Data Principal's) consent is the reason a company (Data Fiduciary) is using
their personal data.And if there is a legal issue or dispute about whether proper consent
was given.Then, the company (Data Fiduciary) must provide proof. The company must
show that it informed the person about how their data would be used. The company must
also prove that the person actually agreed to the data usage.This proof must follow the
legal rules mentioned in the Act.
A company or organization (Data Fiduciary) can process a person's (Data Principal's)
personal data if the person has voluntarily provided it for a specific purpose. Additionally,
the company can continue using the data as long as the person has not explicitly stated
that they do not consent to its use for that purpose.
Illustration 8: (I)X, an individual, makes a purchase at Y, a pharmacy. She voluntarily

Illustration 8: (I)X, an individual, makes a purchase at Y, a pharmacy. She voluntarily
provides her personal data to Y and requests Y to send the payment receipt to her mobile
phone via message. Y can process X's personal data only for the purpose of sending the
receipt.
(II)X, an individual, electronically messages Y, a real estate broker, requesting Y to help
identify a suitable rented accommodation for her and shares her personal data for this
purpose. Y can use X’s personal data only to find a suitable rental house and share the
details with her.However, if X later informs Y that she no longer needs help, Y must
immediately stop using her personal data.
The government and its various departments or agencies can provide to people
(Data Principals) subsidies, benefits, services, certificates, licenses, or permits as per the
rules.Where -
➔ If the person has already agreed/consented to let the government use their

rules.Where -
➔ If the person has already agreed/consented to let the government use their
personal data to provide any of these services, the government can process
their data.
➔ If the person's personal data is already stored digitally, or if it was originally
in a physical (non-digital) format but later converted into a digital format,
and this data is kept in official government records, then the government
can use it.
[]
The use of this data must follow the rules and policies set by the Central
Government or any current law that regulates personal data usage.
Q.why do we need to protect digital protection data ?
The Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023 is a law that protects people's personal data
and ensures that it is used only for legal purposes. It gives individuals the right to control
how their data is collected, used, and shared. Here’s why digital data protection is
important:
1. Lawful Use of Data: Personal data can only be used for valid reasons. This means

important:
1. Lawful Use of Data: Personal data can only be used for valid reasons. This means
companies or organizations must have permission (consent) from the person or use
it only for specific legal purposes.
2. Notice and Permission: Organizations must tell people (data principals) what data
they are collecting, why they need it, and how it will be used. People must give clear
and informed consent before their data is used.
3. Keeping Data Safe: Companies handling personal data must take steps to protect it
from misuse, leaks, or hacking. If a data breach happens, they must inform the Data
Protection Board of India and the affected individuals.
4. People’s Rights Over Their Data: Individuals have the right to:
○ See what personal data is collected about them.
○ Correct any wrong information.
○ Request the deletion of their data.
○ File complaints if their rights are violated.
5. People’s Responsibilities: Individuals should follow the law, avoid giving false

5. People’s Responsibilities: Individuals should follow the law, avoid giving false
information, and not pretend to be someone else.
6. Data Transfer Restrictions: The government can stop personal data from being sent
to other countries if needed for security reasons.
The law also creates the Data Protection Board of India, which ensures that organizations
follow the rules. If a company does not follow the law, it may have to pay heavy fines. This
makes sure that organizations take data protection seriously.
[]
Data security bill india ?
The Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023 is a law that protects personal data and
ensures it is used properly. It sets rules for how companies, organizations, and the
government can collect, store, and use people's digital data.
Key Points of the Act:
1. Purpose:
○ The law ensures that people have the right to protect their personal data.
○ It also allows data to be used for legal and necessary purposes.
2. Where It Applies:

○ It also allows data to be used for legal and necessary purposes.
2. Where It Applies:
○ It applies to all digital data collected in India, whether collected online or
later converted into digital form.
○ It also applies to data collected outside India if it is used to provide services
to people in India.
3. Exceptions:
○ The law does not apply to data used for personal or household activities.
○ If data is already publicly available (like government records), this law does
not apply to it.
4. Responsibilities of Companies (Data Fiduciaries):
○ They must process data only for legal reasons.
○ They must inform people (data principals) about what data is collected and
why.
○ They must take strong security measures to protect data from leaks or
hacking.
○ If there is a data breach, they must inform the government and affected
individuals.
5. People’s Rights (Data Principals):
○ People have the right to know what personal data is being collected.

○ People have the right to know what personal data is being collected.
○ They can request corrections or deletions of their data.
○ They can complain if their data rights are violated.
○ They can assign another person to manage their data if they pass away or
become unable to do so.
6. Data Protection Board of India:
○ A government body that ensures the law is followed and handles complaints
about data misuse.
7. Penalties for Breaking the Law:
○ Companies that fail to protect data can be fined up to ₹250 crore.
[]
This law ensures that personal data is used responsibly and that individuals have control
over their data.
THE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY ACT, 2000
Ques.What is the primary objective of the Information Technology Act, 2000?
The primary objective of the Information Technology Act, 2000 (IT Act, 2000) is to provide
legal recognition to transactions carried out through electronic data interchange and

legal recognition to transactions carried out through electronic data interchange and
other means of electronic communication. It aims to facilitate e-commerce, e-governance,
and secure electronic transactions by providing a legal framework for electronic
signatures, contracts, and records. The Act also addresses cybercrimes and data
protection.
Summary-
The Information Technology Act, 2000 was introduced to manage electronic transactions,
ensure cyber security, and prevent cybercrimes in India. It provides legal recognition to
digital activities and aims to make electronic transactions more secure and reliable.
● The IT Act, 2000 gives legal status to online transactions. This means online
transactions are recognized in the same way as traditional paper-based
transactions.
● The IT Act, 2000, defines electronic and digital signatures and ensures their
authentication. It describes how they can be used to make sure electronic records
are genuine.

authentication. It describes how they can be used to make sure electronic records
are genuine.
● The IT Act, 2000, talks about secure electronic records, which means records that
are protected with security measures. This keeps them safe from tampering.
● The IT Act, 2000, supports e-governance, allowing government agencies to use
electronic records and signatures for things like filing forms and issuing licenses.
● The IT Act, 2000, lists out cybercrimes and their punishments. This includes
things like hacking, identity theft, and spreading viruses.
● The IT Act, 2000, protects intermediaries (like internet service providers) from
being responsible for what other people do online, as long as they follow certain
rules.
● The IT Act, 2000, gives the government the power to monitor and block certain
online content if it's a threat to national security or public order.
● The IT Act, 2000, established CERT-In as the national agency to deal with

● The IT Act, 2000, established CERT-In as the national agency to deal with
cybersecurity incidents. They collect information, give warnings, and coordinate
responses to cyberattacks.
[]
● The IT Act, 2000, also has provisions for protected systems, that allows the
government to declare any computer resource that affects the facility of Critical
Information Infrastructure to be a protected system.
● The IT Act, 2000, includes provisions for ** Examiner of Electronic Evidence**, that
the central government to notify an Examiner of Electronic Evidence to provide
expert opinions in legal settings.
● The IT Act, 2000, aims to align with international standards for electronic
commerce.
● The IT Act, 2000, has been updated over time to deal with new issues like data
protection and cybersecurity.
Cyber Law in India
1. Hacking with Computer Systems & Data Alteration (Section 66 of IT Act)
Section 66 of the Information Technology (IT) Act, 2000 deals with hacking and data

Section 66 of the Information Technology (IT) Act, 2000 deals with hacking and data
alteration, making it illegal to access a computer system or network without permission
and cause damage, steal, or alter data with dishonest or fraudulent intent. This includes
unauthorized access to systems, modifying or deleting digital data, and financial or identity
fraud, such as hacking into a bank’s system, changing school exam marks, or tampering
with medical records. If found guilty, the punishment includes imprisonment of up to 3
years, a fine of up to ₹5 lakh, or both. To prevent hacking, individuals should use strong
passwords, enable two-factor authentication, update security software, avoid suspicious
links, and regularly back up data. This law plays a crucial role in protecting individuals,
businesses, and government entities from cyber threats.
2. Breach of Confidentiality and Privacy (Section 72 of IT Act, 2000)

2. Breach of Confidentiality and Privacy (Section 72 of IT Act, 2000)
Section 72 of the IT Act, 2000, protects confidential and private information from being
disclosed without permission. It applies to anyone who has legal access to such information
due to their job or authority. This includes personal, financial, business, or government
data. If someone misuses or leaks sensitive information without consent, they can be
punished under this law. For example, a bank employee sharing customer financial details
with a fraudster, a doctor revealing a patient’s medical history to an insurance company, or
a government official selling classified information are all violations. The punishment for
this offense includes imprisonment of up to two years, a fine of up to ₹1 lakh, or both. To
[]
prevent such breaches, organizations should have strict data privacy policies, employees
must sign confidentiality agreements, and individuals should report any data breaches to
authorities.

authorities.
3. Sending threatening messages by email Sec .503 IPC
Section 503 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) makes it illegal to send threatening, abusive, or
blackmailing emails to someone. If a person sends an email that threatens to harm another
person, their property, or their reputation, they can be punished under this law. The threat
can be direct or indirect and may involve physical harm, defamation, or financial loss. The
purpose of such emails is usually to create fear or force someone to act against their will.
Examples include sending an email demanding ransom with a threat of harm, blackmailing
someone by threatening to release personal photos, or a cyberbully sending intimidating
messages. The punishment for this offense includes imprisonment of up to two years, a fine,
or both. To prevent such incidents, individuals should never respond to threatening emails
and report them immediately, use spam filters to block unknown senders, and file a

and report them immediately, use spam filters to block unknown senders, and file a
complaint with cyber police if they receive threats.
4. E-mail Spoofing Sec .463 IPC
Email spoofing is a cybercrime where someone creates a fake email ID or changes the
sender’s address to look like a trusted source. This is done to steal personal information,
spread false messages, or commit fraud. Section 463 of the IPC considers email spoofing as
forgery/fraud, making it a punishable offense. In such cases, the sender pretends to be
someone else and uses the fake email to deceive or harm others. The victim believes the
email is real and may act on it. Examples include a scammer pretending to be a bank to steal
account details, a fraudster sending fake emails from a CEO’s account to mislead employees,
or a hacker using a fake government email to spread false news. The punishment includes
imprisonment and a fine, depending on the severity of the fraud. To stay safe, always verify

imprisonment and a fine, depending on the severity of the fraud. To stay safe, always verify
email addresses before responding, check for spelling errors or unusual requests, and avoid
clicking on suspicious links.
5. Unauthorized access to protected system Sec.70
Section 70 of the IT Act, 2000 makes it a serious crime to hack into or access protected
government systems that contain important data related to national security, defense,
banking, or public infrastructure. Unauthorized access to such systems is considered a
major cybercrime. The key elements include that the system must be critical for national
security, the person must access it without permission, and their actions must be
[]
intentional and harmful. For example, a hacker trying to access government defense
servers, a criminal attempting to break into banking systems, or a group of hackers
targeting national power grids are all violations. The punishment for this offense can

targeting national power grids are all violations. The punishment for this offense can
include up to 10 years in prison and a fine, as decided by the court. To prevent such
crimes, government agencies use strong cybersecurity measures, ensure that only
authorized personnel can access sensitive systems, and have cyber monitoring teams to
detect and stop any unauthorized access.
DataBase Security
Database security is about protecting the data stored in databases from being stolen,
damaged, or accessed by unauthorized people. Since databases hold sensitive information
like personal details, bank information, and other private data, it's important to keep them
safe from cybercriminals and other threats.
Why is Database Security Important?
1. Protects Sensitive Data: Databases store important information such as personal
details, banking records, and medical information, which, if exposed, could cause
harm.
2. Prevents Cyber Attacks: Cybercriminals often target databases because they hold

harm.
2. Prevents Cyber Attacks: Cybercriminals often target databases because they hold
valuable information. Strong database security helps prevent attacks.
How to protect the database ?
I. Access Control: This ensures that only authorized users or systems can get into the
database and access sensitive information. There are a few components to this:
➔ Authentication: This process verifies who the user is (for example, by using a
username and password).
➔ Authorization: After verifying who the user is, authorization determines what
actions they can perform (like reading, editing, or deleting data).
➔ Role-Based Access: Different users are given different levels of access based on
their job roles. For example, an admin may have full access, while a regular user
may only be allowed to view the data.
II. Encryption: Encryption is the process of converting data into a secret code, making
it unreadable to anyone who doesn't have the key to unlock it. There are two types
of encryption:

it unreadable to anyone who doesn't have the key to unlock it. There are two types
of encryption:
➔ Encryption at Rest: Protects data when it is stored in the database, ensuring it
is safe even if someone tries to steal the database.
[]
➔ Encryption in Transit: Protects data when it is being sent over the internet,
ensuring it cannot be intercepted or tampered with during transmission.
III. Monitoring and Auditing: This involves regularly checking who is accessing the
database and what they are doing with the data. It helps detect any suspicious or
unauthorized activities. It's like keeping an eye on a security camera to see if
anything unusual happens.
IV. Backups: Backups are copies of the database data stored safely in case something
goes wrong, like a cyberattack or technical failure. If the original data gets damaged
or lost, the backup can restore it to its original state.
V. Patching: Patching means regularly updating the database software to fix any bugs

V. Patching: Patching means regularly updating the database software to fix any bugs
or security flaws. Just like updating your phone or computer software, these
updates help protect the database from new security threats.
VI. Firewalls: A database firewall acts like a security guard that checks and controls the
kind of data that can enter or leave the database. It blocks malicious or harmful
requests from reaching the database, helping to prevent cyberattacks.
VII. Data Masking: Data masking is the process of hiding sensitive information in a way
that makes it look real but isn’t. For example, showing only the last four digits of a
credit card number or social security number, so sensitive data is protected even in
non-production environments.
Common Threats to Database Security
1. SQL Injection Attacks
Hackers use SQL injection to insert harmful commands into the database through
input forms. This could allow them to steal or change data.
2. Unauthorized Access

input forms. This could allow them to steal or change data.
2. Unauthorized Access
People with no permission may try to access the database and steal or alter data.
3. Data Breaches
A data breach happens when someone gets unauthorized access to private data.
This could happen because of hacking, weak security, or mistakes by employees.
4. Malware
Malware (malicious software) can infect databases and damage or steal data.
Ransomware is a type of malware that locks data and demands a payment to unlock
it.
5. Denial of Service (DoS)
DoS attacks happen when hackers overwhelm a system with too many requests,
making it unavailable to users.
[]
Best Ways to Keep Databases Safe
1. Use Strong Authentication
Always use strong passwords and multi-factor authentication (MFA) to protect the
database from unauthorized access.
2. Encrypt Your Data
Ensure all sensitive data is encrypted both when stored and during transmission to
keep it safe from hackers.
3. Backup Your Data

keep it safe from hackers.
3. Backup Your Data
Regularly backup your database so that you can recover data in case of loss or
damage.
4. Keep Software Updated
Apply security patches and updates regularly to fix any vulnerabilities in your
database software.
5. Monitor Database Activity
Set up monitoring tools to watch for unusual activities, such as unauthorized
access or data manipulation.
6. Train Employees
Educate employees on the importance of database security and how to recognize
threats like phishing emails or suspicious links.
SQL Injection
SQL injection is a type of cyberattack where attackers insert or "inject" malicious code
into a website’s SQL (Structured Query Language) database. This code tricks the database
into giving unauthorized access to sensitive data, allowing hackers to steal, modify, or
delete data. SQL injection occurs when a website or web application doesn’t properly
protect itself from untrusted inputs like user queries or data.
How Does SQL Injection Work?

protect itself from untrusted inputs like user queries or data.
How Does SQL Injection Work?
1. Imagine a website where users can log in by entering their username and
password.
2. The website uses SQL to check if the username and password match what’s in the
database. A typical SQL query might look like this:
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = 'user_input' AND password =
'user_password';
[]
3. Malicious Input:A hacker can take advantage of a website's vulnerability by entering
specially crafted input into the form fields. For example, in the username field, the
hacker might enter this: ' OR '1'='1
This makes the query look like:
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = '' OR '1'='1' AND password =
'user_password';
4. In this case, '1'='1' is a statement that is always true, so the SQL query will
return all records from the users table. The hacker has successfully bypassed the
login process without knowing the correct username and password. They can now

login process without knowing the correct username and password. They can now
potentially access all accounts in the database.
Why is SQL Injection Dangerous?
SQL injection can lead to:
● Stealing sensitive data: Hackers can access private information like credit card
numbers, personal details, or passwords.
● Modifying or deleting data: Hackers can change or delete records, damaging data
integrity. For example, they could change account balances or delete users.
● Gaining control of the database: In some cases, attackers can even gain full control
of the database server, leading to the complete compromise of the website or
application.
● Data breaches: If hackers access a large amount of sensitive information, it can lead
to massive data breaches, which could damage a company’s reputation and lead to
legal consequences.
How Can SQL Injection Be Prevented?
1. Input Validation and Sanitization
Always check and clean user input to ensure it doesn’t contain harmful characters

Always check and clean user input to ensure it doesn’t contain harmful characters
like quotes or semicolons that could alter SQL queries.
2. Use Prepared Statements (Parameterized Queries)
Use prepared statements to handle user input securely, where input is treated as
data and not part of the SQL query, preventing injection attacks.
3. Limit Database Permissions
Give users the minimum access they need. For example, only allow read access if
the user doesn’t need to modify or delete data.
[]
4. Error Handling
Avoid displaying detailed error messages to users. Show generic messages to
prevent attackers from gaining information about the database structure.
5. Use Web Application Firewalls (WAF)
WAFs filter and block malicious traffic, detecting and stopping SQL injection
attempts before they reach the server.
6. Regular Security Testing
Regularly perform security audits and penetration tests to find vulnerabilities,

Regularly perform security audits and penetration tests to find vulnerabilities,
including those related to SQL injection, and fix them before attackers exploit
them.
Signs of SQL Injection Attack
● Unusual Database Errors: Unexpected database error messages appearing on your
website.
● Data Integrity Issues: Reports of missing data, altered records, or unexpected
changes.
● Slow Website Performance: SQL injections can sometimes slow down your site if
hackers are running complex queries to extract data.
● Unusual User Activity: An increase in login attempts or activity from unfamiliar IP
addresses.
E-Commerce (Consumer protection and e transaction law)
Who Must Follow These Rules?
1. All e-commerce businesses selling goods or services online, including digital products
(e.g., Amazon, Flipkart, Netflix, Coursera).
2. All types of e-commerce models:
● Marketplace model – Platforms where different sellers list their products (e.g.,
Amazon, Flipkart).

Amazon, Flipkart).
● Inventory model – Platforms that sell their own products directly (e.g., Tata Cliq,
Reliance Digital).
3. All e-commerce retailers, including:
● Single-brand retailers – Brands selling their own products (e.g., Nike, Apple).
● Multi-channel retailers – Brands selling through multiple platforms (e.g., Puma
selling via its website & Amazon).
[]
4. Businesses engaging in unfair trade practices, such as:
● Fake discounts
● False advertising
● Manipulating prices
● Fake reviews
5. Foreign e-commerce companies that are not based in India but sell products or services
to Indian consumers (e.g., Shein, AliExpress, Temu).
These rules do not apply to individuals selling items for personal use, such as someone
selling a second-hand phone on platforms like OLX or WhatsApp.
Definition from the pdf
Duties of e-commerce entities. —
1. Legal Compliance:Every e-commerce company must be registered in India or have

1. Legal Compliance:Every e-commerce company must be registered in India or have
a branch/office in India if it’s a foreign company.They must appoint a responsible
officer in India to ensure compliance with the law.
2. Transparency Requirements:Platforms must clearly display their legal name, office
address, website details, and customer support contacts (including a grievance
officer).
3. Fair Business Practices:Companies cannot engage in unfair trade practices, such as
misleading ads or fake discounts.They must not manipulate prices to gain unfair
profits.
4. Consumer Complaint Handling:Companies must set up a grievance redressal
system and appoint a grievance officer.Complaints must be acknowledged within 48
hours and resolved within one month.
5. Imported Goods: If selling imported goods, they must mention the importer’s
details.
6. Consumer Rights & Protections:No extra cancellation charges for consumers

details.
6. Consumer Rights & Protections:No extra cancellation charges for consumers
unless the platform also pays the same fees if they cancel an order.Explicit consent
must be taken from consumers before purchasing (no pre-ticked checkboxes).
Refunds must be processed quickly as per RBI guidelines.
7. No Discrimination & Price Manipulation:Companies cannot charge unfair prices or
take advantage of demand surges. They cannot discriminate between consumers by
offering different terms unfairly.
Liabilities/Responsibilities of Marketplace E-Commerce Entities
[]
Means The rules and duties these platforms must follow to protect consumers and
ensure fair business practices.
1. Follow IT Laws – They must comply/follow the Information Technology Act, 2000
and its guidelines to avoid legal issues.
2. Ensure Product Accuracy – Platforms must make sure that sellers provide correct
product descriptions, images, and details to avoid misleading consumers.

product descriptions, images, and details to avoid misleading consumers.
3. Display Seller Information – Platforms must clearly show:
● Seller name & business details
● Address and customer support contact
● Ratings and reviews of sellers
● Any other information to help consumers decide before purchase
4. Provide Seller Details on Request – If a customer asks, platforms must share:
● Seller's registered office address
● Website and email details
● Other contact details for dispute resolution
5. Complaint Tracking System – Every customer complaint must have a ticket
number so consumers can track its status.
6. Show Important Policies – Platforms must provide clear information on:
● Return, refund, and exchange policies
● Warranty and guarantee details
● Delivery & shipping costs
● Modes of payment and security details
7. Explain Product Ranking System – Platforms must clarify how they rank products
or sellers and make this information easy to understand.

or sellers and make this information easy to understand.
8. Disclose Favoritism – If they treat certain sellers or brands differently, platforms
must mention this in their terms and conditions.
9. Keep Records of Violating Sellers – Platforms must track sellers who repeatedly
sell illegal or counterfeit products and may ban them if necessary.
Duties of sellers on marketplace:
Sellers who list products or services on marketplace e-commerce platforms like Amazon,
Flipkart, and Meesho must follow specific rules to ensure fairness, transparency, and
consumer protection. These rules cover fair business practices, return and refund policies,
legal requirements, and the information that sellers must provide to e-commerce
platforms.
1. Fair Business Practices
[]
✅
No unfair trade practices – Sellers must not cheat, mislead, or engage in unethical
business practices.
✅
No fake reviews – Sellers cannot post false reviews or pretend to be customers to
mislead buyers.
✅

No fake reviews – Sellers cannot post false reviews or pretend to be customers to
mislead buyers.
✅
No false advertising – Product descriptions must be accurate and not exaggerated.
2⃣ Return, Refund, and Cancellation Rules
✅
Must accept returns – Sellers cannot refuse to take back defective, fake, or incorrect
products.
✅
Must provide refunds – If a product or service does not match what was promised, the
seller must refund the money.
✅
Late delivery exceptions – If delivery is delayed due to natural disasters or unavoidable
circumstances (force majeure), sellers are not responsible.
3⃣ Legal & Customer Support Requirements
✅
Written contract with the platform – Sellers must have a legal agreement with the
e-commerce platform.
✅
Appoint a grievance officer – Sellers must assign a person to handle consumer
complaints, acknowledge complaints within 48 hours, and resolve them within 1 month.
✅
Correct advertising – Ads for products/services must match their real features and

✅
Correct advertising – Ads for products/services must match their real features and
usage conditions.
4⃣ Information That Sellers Must Provide to E-Commerce Platforms
Sellers must give the platform the following details:
✅
Legal name, address, and contact details (including customer support numbers, email,
and website).
✅
GSTIN and PAN details (if applicable).
✅
Total price of the product (with a clear breakdown of taxes, shipping, and other
charges).
✅
All legally required notices (including the expiry date if applicable).
✅
Country of origin – Must mention where the product was manufactured or imported
from.
✅
Importer details – If selling imported goods, sellers must provide importer details and
authenticity guarantees.
✅
Clear return, refund, and exchange policies, including who pays for return shipping.
✅
Delivery and shipping details – Expected delivery time and shipping partners.
✅
Any guarantees or warranties related to the product or service.

✅
Any guarantees or warranties related to the product or service.

Challenges for Consumers on E-Commerce Sites
Shopping online is convenient, but it also comes with challenges. The Consumer
Protection (E-Commerce) Rules, 2020 help protect consumers from fraud and unfair
practices. Below are the common challenges and how consumers are protected from them.
1. Fake or Low-Quality Products
Some sellers deliver counterfeit or defective products instead of genuine ones.
Product descriptions and images may not match the actual product. Lack of proper
quality checks before shipping.
2. Payment Fraud & Hidden Charges
Scams during online payments, such as unauthorized transactions. Some platforms
add hidden charges (e.g., delivery fees, taxes, service charges) at checkout. Unsafe
payment gateways increase the risk of credit/debit card fraud.
3. Delayed or Non-Delivery of Orders
Orders arrive late beyond the promised delivery date. Some sellers fail to deliver

Orders arrive late beyond the promised delivery date. Some sellers fail to deliver
the product at all. No proper tracking system for customers to monitor their
shipment.
4. Difficult Return & Refund Process
Sellers deny returns or refunds for defective or wrong products. Refunds take too
long to process or never get processed. Complicated return policies make it hard
for customers to get their money back.
5. Misleading Advertisements & Fake Reviews
Products look better in online pictures but are different in reality. Sellers post fake
positive reviews to mislead buyers. Customers are tricked by false claims about
product features and discounts.
6. Privacy & Data Security Risks
E-commerce platforms collect personal data and use it for marketing without
consent. Weak security systems expose consumers to identity theft and data leaks.
Consumers receive spam messages and ads due to data misuse.
7. No Proper Complaint Handling

Consumers receive spam messages and ads due to data misuse.
7. No Proper Complaint Handling
Many platforms do not respond to customer complaints properly. No tracking
system to follow up on complaints. Lack of a clear process for reporting fraud,
defective products, or missing deliveries.
[]
8. Price Manipulation & Unfair Discounts
Some platforms increase product prices before showing a discount. Unjustified
price hikes during high demand periods (e.g., festive sales). Sellers inflate prices
unfairly compared to offline stores.
9. Cancellation Charges & Consent Issues
Extra cancellation fees are charged unfairly when customers cancel an order.
Some platforms use pre-ticked checkboxes to trick consumers into agreeing to
extra charges. Consumers may not be informed properly before being charged for
add-ons.
